data.title: Game Crashes On Launch When No Audio Device Exists
data.body:
When you call game.Run(); to start your game a NullException is thrown when no audio devices exist. This might occur, for example, when you start your computer with no speakers plugged in.

Our game doesn't use any SoundEffects etc. This seems to occur regardless. Is there some way for us to fix this?

data.title: [WP8] Fix for music playing after tombstoning and restoring the app, whe...
data.body:
...n already stopped.

To recreate without this fix:
If you start to play a song via MediaPlayer, stop it, then tombstone you app. Once you go back to your app and it restores, the song you previously stopped will begin to play again without any calls to .Play(). Trying to stop it with .Stop() did not work at all.

This applies to Windows Phone 8 only.

data.title: The name 'GamePad' does not exist in the current context
data.body:
Hello, 

Today I was implementing gamepad support and when I try to use the GamePad class, this error occurs: 
The name 'GamePad' does not exist in the current context 

Other classes like GamePadState and GamePadDeadZone are fine. I already uninstalled monogame and installed again, but it does not work. 

There's some problem with GamePad class? 

Environment:
MonoGame: 3.0.1
Visual Studio Express 2012
OS: Windows 8 
Project: WindowsGL 

Thanks

data.title: GameFrameworkViewSource supports the Activated event from the CoreApplic...
data.body: ...ationView class, but that's an old class, which the most recent template doesn't use anymore (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/wiki/Windows-8-Project-Types). The reason that this event is important is to enable game custom protocol activation.

data.title: Android: Implemented Texture2D.SaveAsPng and SaveAsJpeg
data.body:
Also implemented GetData<int>() to make it possible to pass int[] to
Android APIs.

To see an example of it working, check out this repo: https://github.com/jonathanpeppers/MonoGameSaveImage

The sample you can tap the screen, and it will launch an Android intent to open the saved image. You can comment/uncomment code to try JPG or PNG.

data.title: Weird issue with OpenTK
data.body:
Hi!

This message is a continuation of an issue which started in jaquadro's blog, http://jaquadro.com/2013/04/monogame-winforms-repository/

As the problem seems clear to be MonoGame related, I think it's better to continue the discussion here.

On a clean computer, I've downloaded MonoGame latest build from here:

http://build.monogame.net/job/develop-win/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/Installers/Windows/ (2013-10-29 build)

To compare the results, I've also downloaded MonoGame 3.0.1, uninstalled 3.2 build and reinstalled the old version.

I've downloaded MonoGame-WinFormControls latest. I decompress the project and load it (vs2012).  https://github.com/jaquadro/MonoGame-WinFormsControls

My first problem is that for some reason, all MonoGame.Framework references of all projects are referencing to C:\Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0\Assemblies\WindowsPhone\x86\MonoGame.Framework.dll  (the windows phone version).
The OpenTK version is correctly referenced to the WindowsGL path.
I replace all WindowsPhone references to WindowsGL, and rebuild all.

This problem does not appear on MonoGame 3.0.1

Then I run, and the program throws an exception at new GraphicsDevice, but the weird part is that the error is: TypeLoadException was unhandled:  Could not find Windows Runtime type 'SharpDX.WP8.Interop'. Only WindowsGL/MonoGame.Framework.dll and OpenTK.dll are referenced! (that's really weird).

This problem does not appear on monoGame 3.0.1 and the program runs correctly (after changing the parameters of a constructor which has changed to 3.2)

Any ideas?
Thanks a lot!
Kak

data.title: Touch Input Issue WIndows 8 (RT)
data.body:
I just thought I would quickly submit this bug I found here: http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/463287

I will just quote here since Kak already describes it quite perfectly:

"The problem is that sometimes (really often actually) , in Windows RT (Surface RT in my test hardware) when you keep a finger "quiet" in the touch panel, the control lags and even when you release the finger, the touchPanel keeps being pushed (in example, in my platform game the main char keeps moving for a few seconds after I release the touch panel) 

I think that the reason is that sometimes you receive "touches" in WinRT where the pointer hasn't moved at all (same position as before) and this causes the delta movement to be 0. 

Then in TouchLocation.UpdateState, the (delta.LengthSquared() > 0.001f) causes to return false, which makes TouchPanel.GetState() not being able to process all the buffered events as it returns at the first TouchPanel.RefreshState call.

Once the deltas are 0, only 1 event is consumed each frame in the GetState function, producing the lag. 

It seems also that Surface RT "emits" this kind of messages very often, so if your game is very intensive, the lag increases. "

I can reproduce the very same issue on my Dell XPS 10 (which is running WindowsRT as well).

data.title: Renamed ContentManager.ReadRawAsset<T> to LoadRawAsset<T> and made it public
data.body:
Since we plan on removing ReadRawAsset altogether, you are probably asking why. Two reasons:
- Lets us avoid the expected ContentLoadException when loading every raw content item. Having an expected exception makes debugging difficult when you want to "break on thrown".
- It's a transitional step for people who still rely on raw assets. When the content pipeline is done, we can remove the raw asset loading code completely, but in the mean time we can give developers the option of explicitly asking the ContentManager to load their raw assets.

For now, I've not altered the existing functionality. I'm not sure whether now is the right time to disable the default "try to load raw asset when xnb not found" functionality. What do others think?

data.title: Fix DictionaryReader.Read when existing instance supplied
data.body: This can occur on Android when reloading subclassed Texture2D sprite sheets (ie when a dictionary is used to store named texture regions)

data.title: Finally a fix for the WP8 debug bug
data.body: Fixed the slowdowns that occur when debugging WP8 and dragging the screen. If anyone has any idea why this was the cause, let me know.

data.title: MGCB building Spritefonts wrong on Mac OS X
data.body:
After seeing that pull request #2068 added support for building Spritefonts with the newly-introduced `FontTextureProcessor` on Linux and Mac, I decided to try it out. However, after getting MGCB built, and building a test `.spritefont` file and putting it into my game, I noticed a clear issue:
![Spritefont example](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1362179/1414565/06a0a3e0-3e93-11e3-9dfe-0a8aaebf165c.png)

I downloaded another pre-compiled Spritefont, and it doesn't exhibit the same issue; meaning that this is an issue with the builder, not the runtime. It appears that the new processor doesn't account for font baselines. However, it may also be important to note that I was also getting the following error with the builder (which is odd, since the `xnb` file was still saved, and could be dropped into the game):

```
Building Font /Library/Fonts/Microsoft Sans Serif.ttf
Building Font /Library/Fonts/Microsoft Sans Serif.ttf
Detected Windows using DXT Compression
System.DllNotFoundException: nvtt
  at (wrapper managed-to-native) Nvidia.TextureTools.Compressor:nvttCreateCompressor ()
  at Nvidia.TextureTools.Compressor..ctor () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.GraphicsUtil.CompressDxt (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.TextureContent content, Boolean generateMipmaps) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.GraphicsUtil.CompressTexture (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.TextureContent content, Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentProcessorContext context, Boolean generateMipmaps, Boolean premultipliedAlpha) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Processors.FontDescriptionProcessor.Process (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.FontDescription input, Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentProcessorContext context) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 

Build 1 succeeded, 0 failed.

Time elapsed 00:00:02.12.

Unhandled Exception:
System.DllNotFoundException: nvtt
  at (wrapper managed-to-native) Nvidia.TextureTools.Compressor:nvttDestroyCompressor (intptr)
  at Nvidia.TextureTools.Compressor.Finalize () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
```

I only tested this on Mac OS X (10.9), so I can't say whether or not the same issue exists on Linux or Windows.

data.title: GameComponents.Add() and Initializing GameComponents
data.body:
Solve https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2105
Related to
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/c1544bce033f1d0432bb3ef360aef1707af15976

This is closer to XNA behavior.
-Initialization of Components is postponed until the call to
base.Initialize(...).
-Components added inside the virtual Initialize(...) but after the call
to base.Initialize(...) need to be self initialized.
-Components added later are auto-initialized.

data.title: Support for Texture2D.FromStream on WP8
data.body: This one is hassle-free compared to #1948.

data.title: GameComponents.Add() and Initializing GameComponents
data.body:
I wanted to ask about this commit here:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/c1544bce033f1d0432bb3ef360aef1707af15976

This caused a number of crashes on several of my titles, but looking at the XNA4 spec it _should_ make sense... however, we have this test case here:

http://pastebin.com/bDG4yZUG

(Thanks to Nick Gravelyn for the test case!)

It appears that the only time it does NOT Initialize a Component automatically is after base.Initialize(); is called, and only for the remainder of the developer's Game.Initialize() method. For Draw and Update, Components added should be initialized, according to this test case.

So the code in that commit at least fixed it for that one block of time, but broke it for all the others. Not sure how this should be fixed, or if reverting it is better in the short term.

data.title: Fix WindowsGL project template : use the right Program Files folder and ...
data.body:
...fix an issue with the resolving of assembly references finding the WindowsPhone ones before the Windows ones (error was MessageFilterHook type not found when launching a new WindowsGL project).

Commit message is self-explanatory. I was not able to compile and run a newly created Windows GL project using Windows build #280 from the Jenkins build server. These fixes solve the issues I had.

data.title: Windows 8.1 Monogame+XAML Touch events keep firing
data.body:
Heey,

We released a game one week back and it all goes well but after upgrading to windows 8.1 we got a small bug which we can't fix.

What changed?

In windows 8.1 they changed a thing that when you activate a XAML textbox with touch and thereby activating the onscreen keyboard they shove now not only the textbox up so it stands above the onscreen keyboard no, they now shove your whole app up so your onscreen keyboard stays on the bottom and your whole game will be partially squeezed out of the frame. You can now swipe up and down in the area above your onscreen keyboard to move your app/game around.

What goes wrong?

If you just insert some input and focus another element it goes fine and nothing strange happens but when you move the game/app up and down while the onscreen keyboard is active and you then exit it by focusing another element it will keep firing a touch event while there isn't anything happening the TouchPanel.GetState() keeps giving old and random touch input.

How to reproduce

I recreated the bug in this project and thereby kinda proved it isn't anything project specific I maybe did wrong. https://www.dropbox.com/s/7rziu3m8l0mk0q9/XAML%20Textinput.rar
1. Touch on the screen so the Textbox and Button will appear
2. Touch the textbox so the onscreen keyboard appears
3. Type a letter and move the screen above the onscreen keyboard up and down
4. Press enter on the keyboard or tap the button on the left side of the screen
5. Set a breakpoint inside the Update() inside the if(touches.Count != 0) and watch the breakpoint being hit.

Hope my explanation is clear enough. This isn't the worst thing but it can be really frustrating when a player gets a sweet highscore then types in his/her name and accidentally swipes the screen and thereby cause the game to jam itself because the touch events are spammed and thereby uncontrollable which may result in low ratings D:

Fixed some warnings on the PSM version, implemented some of the DrawUser
functions for PSM, however something like VertexPositionColor will not
work for now (on PSM).

data.title: MonoGame tests fail to load content
data.body:
The tests currently set the content root directory to an absolute path (ie. Content.RootDirectory = AppDomain.CurrentDomain.BaseDirectory). XNA happily accepts this, but MonoGame does not which results in a lot of tests failing because they can't load any content.

So is MonoGame meant to support absolute paths like XNA does, or is it intentional that it only supports relative paths (eg. for cross-platform compatibility)?

data.title: RenderTarget improvements
data.body:
- Add MSAA support when available (WindowsGL, iOS and Android)
- Add render to cubemap support
- Better Framebuffer object management

This is a big change that add proper RenderTarget support (MSAA + Cubmap + MRT) on all GL platforms. Due to the complexity supporting RenderTarget on mobile platforms, I moved all the GL calls inside the GraphicsDevice class; this makes it a lot easier to maintain a clean code. I would strongly advise that we do this for all graphics resources and separate each API in its own GraphicsDevice implementation (will be necessary to support GLES3.0 along with GLES2.0).

This PR might have a few issue due to other changes in the GraphicsDevice that I couldn't test but I wanted to send this to have ppl review it, discuss it, test it and eventually improve it.

data.title: Update Libs to SharpDX 2.5.
data.body: Required for #2059

data.title: BasicEffect.EmissiveColor oversaturate a model.
data.body:
This is for a model with Texture.
Everything else is off, 
AmbientLightColor =0,
LightingEnabled = false
VertexColorEnabled = false,
etc...

with: DiffuseColor = 1/EmissiveColor =0
MonoGame & XNA draws the model correctly.

with: DiffuseColor = 1/EmissiveColor =1
MonoGame draws the model oversaturated. XNA draws it correct, same as before.

I guess XNA put a ceiling on its shader while MonoGame accumulate the result from   DiffuseColor  & EmissiveColor.

data.title: Make Texture2D.Reload(Stream) public -- again
data.body:
Someone already did this in a previous commit ( https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/06f6c2fe65201fd3552af1261711af07fbc51cf3 ) but I think it inadvertently got lost in a merge...
I'm not sure why nobody missed it, but my team and I are using this method on Android, to recover from the GraphicsDevice.DeviceReset event. To quote the original commit message:

"The ContentManager class handles texture reloading of all its loaded textures, but if you're using Texture2D.FromStream() to load textures, this change will allow you to reload them without updating their references everywhere."

data.title: Added ScissorRectangle reset after render target change
data.body: According to XNA behavior the ScissorRectangle should be reset to match the new render target size after render target change.

data.title: Latest OpenGL build crashes on launch with "FileNotFound" exception for SharpDX.RawInput
data.body:
Guessing this is a simple pre-compiler tag issue but somehow the GL build is looking for SharpDX dlls?

Simple to replicate, start a new Windows project and use the latest NuGet MonoGame package.
Using the 3.0.1 package has no issues.

data.title: Get/Set Texture issue on ATI graphics cards
data.body:
Get/Set Texture issue on ATI graphics cards using the latest source of monogame.

When I run the same code on 4 machines the 2 that use ATI graphics cards (and when not using a software renderer like warp) produce huge artefacts on the textures that I get via get data and then set via set data to turn render targets into texture2ds that are also stored in system memory.

Here a screenshot of the issue, left is the ati cards, right is correct on intel, NVidia and warp.

![untitled1](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2770203/1342490/c71f3a32-3664-11e3-944a-80b623004c16.png)

I saw a pull request (I think) about 3 months ago about the same or a similar ATI issue but cannot find any history of it and the current source still has the issue. I believe it has something to do with how ATI store there textures in memory but I can't remember.
